abstract.text: Returns the next event matching a given mask, or
if no such event is found before a specified expiration date.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Contains one or more flags indicating the types of events to return. The constants section of the
class defines the constants you can add together to create this mask. The
method also lists several of these constants.
The expiration date for the current event request. Specifying nil for this parameter is equivalent to returning a date object using the
method.
The run loop mode in which to run while looking for events. The mode you specify also determines which timers and run-loop observers may fire while the app waits for the event.
Specify
if you want the event removed from the queue.
The event object whose type matches one of the event types specified by the
parameter.

You can use this method to short circuit normal event dispatching and get your own events. For example, you may want to do this in response to a mouse-down event in order to track the mouse while its button is down. (In such an example, you’d pass the appropriate event types for mouse-dragged and mouse-up events to the
parameter and specify the
run loop mode). Events that don’t match one of the specified event types are left in the queue.
You can specify one of the run loop modes defined by AppKit or a custom run loop mode used specifically by your app. AppKit defines the following run-loop modes:

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
An object that manages an app’s main event loop and resources used by all of that app’s objects.
The last event object that the app retrieved from the event queue.
Removes all events matching the given mask and generated before the specified event.
Activates the app, opens any files specified by the
user default, and unhighlights the app’s icon.
A Boolean value indicating whether the main event loop is running.
Returns the next event matching a given mask, or
if no such event is found before a specified expiration date.
Adds a given event to the receiver’s event queue.
Starts the main event loop.
Starts a modal event loop for the specified window.
Dispatches an event to other objects.
Stops the main event loop.
An object that contains information about an input action, such as a mouse click or a key press.
Constants that you use to filter out specific event types from the stream of incoming events.
The mode set when tracking events modally, such as a mouse-dragging loop.
A date object representing a date in the distant past.
A true value.
Type to represent a Boolean value.
Modes that a run loop operates in.
A representation of a specific point in time, for use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
The programmatic interface to objects that manage input sources.
A specific point in time, independent of any calendar or time zone.
A value type whose instances are either `true` or `false`.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.

Specify
if you want the event removed from the queue.
The event object whose type matches one of the event types specified by the
parameter.

value.text: A representation of a specific point in time, independent of any calendar or time zone.
